values.author: Student7
values.title: 50 created by Student7
values.description:
Share code with Jazz Source Control

To share code in your Eclipse workspace with the Jazz stream created during process initialization:

1. Select a project you wish to share, right-click and select Team->Share Project...

2. In the Share Project Wizard, select Jazz Source Control and select Next.

3. If you have more than one repository connection, you will be prompted to choose one. On the Jazz Repository page, select the repository in which you created your project area and select Next.

4. On the Select Component page, you should see a repository workspace prefixed with the name of the project area you created.

Expand this repository workspace and you will see a component. Select this component and select Next. Review the ignored resources on the next page and then select Finish to share your code with the specified component and repository workspace.

5. Now that the code has been shared to your repository workspace, you need to deliver it from your workspace to the stream created during initialization of the process. To do this, open the Pending Changes view.

6. In the Pending Changes view, you should see one outgoing change from your repository workspace. Right-click on the repository workspace and select Deliver to deliver your code to the stream associated with your team area.

For additional details on using Jazz Source Control, consult the Getting Started with Jazz Source Control help topic.

See any terms you don't recognize? You may also wish to consult the Jazz Platform Quick Reference.

values.author: Student7
values.title: 51 created by Student7
values.description:
Define phases

When the project area was initialized, an initial timeline "Main Development" was created. Within the timeline a hierarchy of phases has been created for you.

To edit, delete, duplicate or add additional timelines and phases:

1. Open the Project Area Editor by right-clicking on the project area in the Team Artifacts or Team Organization view and selecting Open.

2. Go to the Timelines section in the editor. To create a new phase, use either the Create Phase... action or the Duplicate... action on an existing phase.

3. To define the start and end dates for an existing phase, use the Edit Properties... action on an existing phase.

For additional details on using Jazz Team Process, consult the Getting Started with Projects, Teams, and Process help topic.

See any terms you don't recognize? You may also wish to consult the Jazz Platform Quick Reference.

values.author: Student7
values.title: 53 created by Student7
values.description:
Define the team members for the project area as well as the team area

To define team members for a team area or project area:

1. Open the team area or project area editor by right-clicking on the project or team area in the Team Artifacts or Team Organization view and selecting Open.

2. On the Overview page of the editor, there is a Members section. To add a user to the team select the Add button. To create a new user and add them as a member of the team, select the Create button

3. If you clicked Add, in the Add Team Members dialog, select the user(s) you wish to add to your team or project area. If you clicked Create, define the new team member in the Create User wizard.

4. Consider what roles individuals working on your project will assume and what role-specific process should apply to each role. In addition, you will want to consider what permissions to grant to individuals in these roles. For additional details on using Jazz Team Process, consult the Getting Started with Projects, Teams, and Process help topic.

5. On Save of the editor you will be prompted to send invitations to the newly added team members. This allows you to configure an email invitation that is sent to the new team member. The new team member can accept the invitation with File->Accept Team Invitation.... The invitation will quickly setup their Eclipse workspace to work with the team. At any time you can invite team members to join the team by selecting the team member in the Members section, right click and select Invite to Join Team....

See any terms you don't recognize? You may also wish to consult the Jazz Platform Quick Reference.

values.author: Student6
values.title: 97 created by Student6
values.description:
A first cut at requirements is a pre-requisite for doing any planning. You cannot plan if you do not know what you are attempting to build. Begin with the proposal, and work with the client to elicit and refine the requirements. Requirements will evolve over time, so you need to maintain an active requirements document.
Each specific requirement must be uniquely numbered for easy identification and be prioritized (ranked based on value to the client, e.g., low, medium, or high).
Diagrams, if any, should be legible. Use UML notation if applicable, rather than your own notation.

Client-oriented Requirements:

-required features (i.e., services that the product must support)
-application domain model (i.e., key entities, relationships, and attributes in the client's problem domain)
-workflow model (i.e., how the client interacts with the product in terms of user tasks)
-qualities (non-functional requirements such as response time, memory size, etc.)

Developer-oriented Requirements:

-architectural aspects (e.g., a candidate architecture)
-external interfaces (i.e., relationships to other required hardware, software, and data)
-conventions (e.g., coding or user interface styles to be followed)

External Requirements

There are some requirements that neither the client or developer have direct control over. Examples include regulatory conditions (e.g., privacy, Sarbanes-Oxley, etc.), organizational policies or constraints, and externally imposed software processes (deliverables, deadlines, etc.).

values.author: Student1
values.title: 105 created by Student1
values.description:
First of all, the 301's are developing Android apps (with Jazz)... thus you can use their development environment in `cd /c301`.

Otherwise the first step is to download Android SDK. http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html
Once you download that, run `android`.
You'll want to install the "android SDK tools" and "android SDK platform tools"
You'll also want to download the SDK for version 2.2 and 2.33 (which has 30% and 55% market share: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Android_chart.png)
You also need a system image if you want to run a virtual machined android.

Android is usually developed on eclipse using their Android Plugin (ADT). http://developer.android.com/sdk/eclipse-adt.html

The latest Jazz RTC uses Eclipse v3.5 (Galileo).
Latest ADT only supports v3.6 so instead download an older ADT version: http://dl.google.com/android/ADT-15.0.1.zip
But first you will need to add an Eclipse update repository to your settings, see: http://code.google.com/intl/es/eclipse/docs/faq.html#wstinstallerror 
Then you should be able to install the ADT.

Now from my understanding, you probably won't be able to automatically have ADT running an app for you because it only works using Sun's/Oracle Java. (see last post: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=350457).
Thus we must compile/save it manually to the VM. First thing is do: `android update project -p PATHNAME`.
Then you should be able to compile it: either `ant debug` or `ant release`
And finally transferring it to the VM: `ant installd` or `ant install`

Things I might have forgotten to talk about: 
- how to setup the VM (HVGA has smaller resolution, meaning faster VM)
-  (comment) We should be testing at minimum 800x480, because that's what a majority of devices run, or qHD (960x540)
- allowing app transfers to the VM (must set in developer mode somewhere in the setting to enable USB app transfer)
-  (comment) no need, the VM already can transfer the app without problems.
- starting up the VM
-  (comment) VM is autostarted when you run the application in eclipse.

(comment) All of these details aren't really all that necessary. The default environment that you set up, if you run eclipse then install the ADT will set up the appropriate settings for doing stuff.

values.title: 120 created by Student4
values.description:
2 Risk AssessmentsThis is an ongoing list of potential risks that could cause your project to fail (e.g., not meet requirements, miss the schedule, etc.). Categories of risks include:

-scope (e.g., expanding requirements, poor change control);
-technology (e.g., areas in which exploration and research are needed);
-personnel (e.g., missing expertise, loss of trust);
-schedule (e.g., unreasonable timetable);
-client (e.g., lack of feedback, availability);
-other (e.g., natural disaster, loss of interest, etc.).
For each identified risk, assess its potential impact (high, medium, low) and likelihood (high, medium, low), and rank the risks. For risks with high/medium impact or high/medium likelihood, describe mitigation plans to soften the problem or contingency plans to proactively avoid the risk. Provide indicators that would signal the risk has occurred and requires action.

values.author: Student4
values.title: 122 created by Student4
values.description:
4 Major Scheduled Items

This is a preliminary development schedule to identify major activities of the plan and their sequence among one another. For large projects, it is usually summarized in the form of a Gantt or network diagram. For small projects, a series of simple tables is sufficient (see example below).

Use two-level planning (i.e., release planning to roughly map out a series of two-week iterations or time boxes, and iteration planning to add details for a particular iteration). Each iteration should have a table and corresponding work items and iterations should be defined in your Jazz project area

.Activity              Planned/Estimated                                                        Actual
                            Start Date    End Date      Effort (person hours)         Start Date  End Date     Effort (person hours)
....                         ...............      ...........             ....                                          ...                  .....                ...    


A fully detailed iteration plan will include effort estimates and who is responsible for each activity. Iterations that are further into the future are expected to have relatively less detail in the beginning and to be revised as more information becomes known.


Example activities include:
-development tasks to support delivery of value to the client;
-testing and validation/verification tasks;
-post-review repair tasks;
-delivery, installation, and acceptance test tasks;
-client training and support tasks;
-evaluation or learning tasks;-
-planning for the next iteration.

Planning for the next iteration can be discussed at the "Friday client meeting". Typically, the current iteration ends soon after this next plan has been detailed.

Actual effort data will require team members to maintain time logs of their individual activities. This should be updated periodically for monitoring the level of progress. A summary of actual resource allocation is expected at the end of the project.

values.title: 121 created by Student4
values.description:
3 Project Macro-Structure

This section describes the overall software process for the project. The kind of project will affect your choice of management process, development practices, and team organization. You need to determine and describe:

-the kind of project (e.g., exploratory/creative, tactical execution, or focused problem resolution);
-the process model used (has to be evolutionary, possibly agile) and the particular choices and/or adaptations you may decide to adopt;
-the team management model chosen and reasons why (e.g., egoless, chief programmer team, etc.);
-the anticipated roles in the development team (e.g., technical lead, management lead, tester, etc.);
-the project-monitoring mechanisms (agile processes should include measurements such as velocity, burndown charts).

Pointer to time log information for the team members. Instructions on how to do that with Jazz will be given in the lab.The Plan as the Management Document

The project plan should be regularly updated, at the time of the major scheduled releases of your product. In this manner it will serve as the "Managment Document" for your project and, in the end, it will be delivered as part of the complete project documentation.

As major scheduled items are completed, the document should be updated with the actual dates and efforts for your project activities, and any major deviations between the planned and actual execution of an activity should be explained.

values.author: Student6
values.title: 178 created by Student6
values.description:
Requirements Technical Review
There are many kinds of requirements review. This review will focus on checking that the content of the requirements document is correct, complete, consistent, clear, and realistic. The document may also include reviewer guidelines that outline specific issues to consider.Review Process
The following three step review process will be used.

1. Preparation (before class)
The main technical material to be considered is the requirements document. The project glossary and information sources may also need to be consulted besides the specific requirements.
Each reviewer examines the requirement document to:
-locate as many defects as possible (e.g., an error or omission that would prevent the product from performing one or more of its tasks in normal use, like omitting a business object);
-identify high-risk areas in terms of quality and potential implementation issues (e.g., a situation where the requirements seem incomplete, too rigid, or too shallow to handle all the situations that might occur);
-highlight any concerns (e.g., a situation where the requirements are correct and complete, but could be improved say in terms of complexity or reusability).
For example, some constraint in the requirements may not be reflected in the client model. For example, if there is a need for concurrent access to a database, then the client model needs to have some way of handling transactions that cannot be posted because the data assumed by the transaction has changed.
Classify the findings into major, moderate, or minor levels of severity:
-major (the repair for the problem is not obvious, and a very careful further review is required);
-moderate (the repair for the problem is straightforward, but needs to be further reviewed);
-minor (the fix is either unnecessary or obvious, and there is no need for further review).
For each requirements document, complete a requirements review report containing these findings. Preparation time should be no more than 3 hours per reviewer per document.

2. Collection and discussion meeting
Before the meeting a moderator and recorder will be identified. The moderators are pre-assigned according the the schedule at the end of this description. The instructor and TAs will be the moderators for one half of the reviews and members of the reviewing teams will be the moderators for the other half of the reviews. A member of the authoring team should be the recorder. The authors of the requirements document, or someone familiar with the contents, must be available during the meeting as a resource person (with a copy of the document on-hand).

The findings reports should be printed out by the reviewers before the meeting.
During a 25 minute meeting, the collected findings will be discussed and potentially re-classified. Discussions on minor issues will be held to a minimum. The authors are not expected to respond during the meeting to every question or comment raised, but the recorder should note down the issue. The authors are present primarily to better understand the findings.Hints
A good checklist of things to look for is in Section 2Functional Specification Reviews, of the Handbook of Walkthroughs, Inspections, and Technical Reviews by Daniel P. Freedman and Gerald M. Weinberg, 3rd edition (August 1990) Dorset House; ISBN: 0932633196.
(See https://eclass.srv.ualberta.ca/file.php/343/material2011/Formal_technical_Review_BeyondTest_Focusing_Quality_Everywhere.pdf )
Reviewers should use the following suggested structure (or something very similar) to help prepare their findings report. Number the findings sequentially, sorted by severity (major, moderate, then minor). Note the location within the document for the finding. Enter a brief but clear description.

Requirements Technical Review Findings Report
Reviewing Team #:
Reviewer Name(s):
Authoring Team #:
Document Name:

Statistics
Number of major findings:
Number of moderate findings:
Number of minor findings:
Person hours of review effort:

Evaluation
The reviews will be assessed on their depth, accuracy, thoroughness, and helpfulness. Two-thirds (66.6%) of the marks for Project Part 2 will be assigned to the Technical Review document and one-third (33.3%) will be assigned to the repair efforts of each teamThe detailed schedule of reviews, including reviewer assignments, moderators and rooms will be published after the first deliverable.

values.author: Student5
values.title: 178 modified by Student5
values.description:
Requirements Technical Review
There are many kinds of requirements review. This review will focus on checking that the content of the requirements document is correct, complete, consistent, clear, and realistic. The document may also include reviewer guidelines that outline specific issues to consider.Review Process
The following three step review process will be used.

1. Preparation (before class)
The main technical material to be considered is the requirements document. The project glossary and information sources may also need to be consulted besides the specific requirements.
Each reviewer examines the requirement document to:
-locate as many defects as possible (e.g., an error or omission that would prevent the product from performing one or more of its tasks in normal use, like omitting a business object);
-identify high-risk areas in terms of quality and potential implementation issues (e.g., a situation where the requirements seem incomplete, too rigid, or too shallow to handle all the situations that might occur);
-highlight any concerns (e.g., a situation where the requirements are correct and complete, but could be improved say in terms of complexity or reusability).
For example, some constraint in the requirements may not be reflected in the client model. For example, if there is a need for concurrent access to a database, then the client model needs to have some way of handling transactions that cannot be posted because the data assumed by the transaction has changed.
Classify the findings into major, moderate, or minor levels of severity:
-major (the repair for the problem is not obvious, and a very careful further review is required);
-moderate (the repair for the problem is straightforward, but needs to be further reviewed);
-minor (the fix is either unnecessary or obvious, and there is no need for further review).
For each requirements document, complete a requirements review report containing these findings. Preparation time should be no more than 3 hours per reviewer per document.

2. Collection and discussion meeting
Before the meeting a moderator and recorder will be identified. The moderators are pre-assigned according the the schedule at the end of this description. The instructor and TAs will be the moderators for one half of the reviews and members of the reviewing teams will be the moderators for the other half of the reviews. A member of the authoring team should be the recorder. The authors of the requirements document, or someone familiar with the contents, must be available during the meeting as a resource person (with a copy of the document on-hand).

The findings reports should be printed out by the reviewers before the meeting.
During a 25 minute meeting, the collected findings will be discussed and potentially re-classified. Discussions on minor issues will be held to a minimum. The authors are not expected to respond during the meeting to every question or comment raised, but the recorder should note down the issue. The authors are present primarily to better understand the findings.Hints
A good checklist of things to look for is in Section 2Functional Specification Reviews, of the Handbook of Walkthroughs, Inspections, and Technical Reviews by Daniel P. Freedman and Gerald M. Weinberg, 3rd edition (August 1990) Dorset House; ISBN: 0932633196.
(See https://eclass.srv.ualberta.ca/file.php/343/material2011/Formal_technical_Review_BeyondTest_Focusing_Quality_Everywhere.pdf )
Reviewers should use the following suggested structure (or something very similar) to help prepare their findings report. Number the findings sequentially, sorted by severity (major, moderate, then minor). Note the location within the document for the finding. Enter a brief but clear description.

Requirements Technical Review Findings Report
Reviewing Team #:
Reviewer Name(s):
Authoring Team #:
Document Name:

Statistics
Number of major findings:
Number of moderate findings:
Number of minor findings:
Person hours of review effort:

Evaluation
The reviews will be assessed on their depth, accuracy, thoroughness, and helpfulness. Two-thirds (66.6%) of the marks for Project Part 2 will be assigned to the Technical Review document and one-third (33.3%) will be assigned to the repair efforts of each teamThe detailed schedule of reviews, including reviewer assignments, moderators and rooms will be published after the first deliverable.

values.author: Student4
values.title: 318 created by Student4
values.description:
Due to time constrains and due to the xcode simulator shitting out on me today, I was unable to hook up the profiles.

FUTURE MAINTANANCE:
 The majority of the framework was implemented to support profiles and it is about a days work to get profiles to function. I didn't do it since i only had a day left and between documentation and the fact that i did not want to break functionality I left it for another time. If the client cares I can hook it up during the summer. To hook up the framework is rather simple. Create 2 new entities in the Core Data folder, one for profile names and the other needs to contain profileName, userSubstanceName, actualSubtanceName, substanceType.
Than in the searchViewController simply have set the usersList, NHPList, and the drugList to contain the right elemetns from the two new entites.
The profileViewController would need the MOC passed to it so that i can properly delete the right rows in the entties based on which profile the user deletes from this view.

I also suggest makign a new NSUserDefault attriubt that states which profile is loaded, and when it swtiches to a new profile change the variable accordingly. This way each time the
 search view is loaded, the controller knowws where to get the data from.

Note that i also laid down the persistentStore coordinator and that would of saved all the actions the user did making the profiles and auto-save feature.

values.author: Student1
values.title: 280 created by Student1
values.description:
Should we maybe save each Activity into a global State, reusing the Activity instead of creating new ones each time?

For example, going to Search, then clicking in the ActionBar the Home button creates a new NHPDashboard Activity (which checks the Version online again, tries to restart the DB, etc...)
Clicking back twice get's back to the old NHPDashboard Activity (a different one).

Might be smart to make Activities globally unique instead of creating new ones, and keeping them all in memory.


Nick's comments:
Used launchMode = singleTop, as per developer suggestions.
